narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A much better use of analytical reasoning.
I did not learn or develop any skills from this course.

I learned strong insights about past and current political and economic events in African countries. The most interesting parts of the course were when it focused on infrastructure, economic development, and their relationship with country stability.
learned some about how foreign aid to the continent works and about peacekeeping efforts on the continent by multilateral organizations such as the UN, also about continental organizations

This is a good class to take if you want to learn more about international relations and how it applies to Africa. Professor Simon was so accomodating throughout the whole class. He made sure to assign manageable workload that wouldn't overwhelm us but still let us learn

I learned about foreign aid, peacekeeping, and the African Union in the context of African international relations. I also was able to connect with some of our guest speakers and learned more about their backgrounds and experiences beyond the classroom! Also, I think this course helped me learn how to organize my thoughts, and quickly and efficiently write due to our in-class essays.

I learned a lot about African politics and history since the end of World War II. I also learned about the UN, World Bank, and IMF's involvement in African governance and economic development, as well as a number of specific conflicts that have taken place on and shaped the continent in recent decades.

I learned a great deal about theories of international relations since this was my first IR course, but I also learned a great deal about African history and politics that helped contextualize these theories really well

I learned about liberalism, radicalism, realism, regime security theory. I also learned about African Union, I just think everything connected back to the international relations perspectives and we used them to examine things in Africa

I was able to develop an in depth understanding of the various dynamics of African international relations ranging from donor aid functions to peacekeeping and African regional and continental organizations
This course provides an insight into the overall themes of Africa in International Relations and some case studies.
Critical thinking in situational circumstances and the sensitivity of international relations
Foreign aid in Africa, peacekeeping and peacebuilding in Africa, and the possibility for African integration

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths are the material and the discussion section format. Weaknesses are the quantity and usage of reading assignments.

This course seemed all over the place at times. The readings never connected well with any of the lectures. Often times the lectures seemed confusing, especially with the jumping around by the instructor to certain bullet points on the powerpoint. There was also no clear communication going on between the TF and the instructor so every time we'd ask the TF a question they couldn't answer because they didn't know what the instructor wanted. There was also never a clear outline to how the professor wanted assignments done, and the person grading them we didn't know so we couldn't go over how to improve them because try limited comments were given on assignments. It was also not clear what we were supposed to be learning or taking away from the assignments so at times they didn't make sense. The quizzes were pretty difficult because there was little information given on how to study or what to study, and the amount of time given to take them with the requirement of them being essays was not good because it felt like a huge rush and I was't providing my best possible work or understanding of the quiz question. The 20 minute tutorials every week also seemed pointless because that is such a short amount of time barely anyone really anticipates because theres not enough time for every to delve into a topic our idea. The topics that were brought up barely covered the main point of the weeks lectures or even readings, so it just did not help facilitate any learning for the course.
Overall, it was a fantastic class. I wish there was more time in the discussion sections but other than that, it was great.

sometimes assignments were unclear and changed closer to the due date; synchronous lectures and guest speakers were interesting, but didn't relate sometimes to the unit; also didn't really get much use out of the twenty minute "tutorials" since they were so short

Strengths: The "lecturelette" format was super nice and really helped break up screen time for students with strained eyes. Also the material was engaging all around and I appreciated the mix of academic theory and writing with op-eds and online articles in the readings for the week. Assignments and quizzes were few but clearly structured to further understanding of the material.

Weaknesses: Reading each week was over 100 pages and oftentimes a lot of it did not seem as "necessary" to understanding the week's topic as others. Additionally, reading seemed to be kind of a waste because section was only 25 mins long, which was not nearly enough time to talk through even a quarter of what was read.

I liked how we reserved class time for discussions with Professor Simon and our peers because our debrief of the readings and lectures allowed for me to gain a better understanding of the learned material. I wished we engaged with more African professionals because I feel as if we should give them a space to voice their own opinions and stories in a class based on the African identity (I really loved the Evan Mawarire class!). I feel as though storytelling is really important in African culture, and when we bring African professionals to tell their stories we gain a better understanding of the topic at hand.

Lots of content which was good and interesting. I didn't do much of the reading, but that was fine and I guess overall made me less engaged in the course. For a fairly broad lecture during COVID, it was about as good as it could have been.
Great course, but I think a lot of pod time was spent just rehashing material because the readings/lectures/guest speaker topics were never quite congruent with one another

Prof never posted lectures we'd have to watch for class on time. Had a lot of late nights just because he would post them hours to the class the evening before and expect us to have seen them by the time we met the next morning. Even after we asked him to, he didn't change this much.

The strength was that it was a good amount of assignments that were not super difficult. I believe there could have been less, but honestly not an overwhelming class to take. It was a bit redundant at times, but it's a good fifth course to take.

strengths: amazing lectures, great guest speakers, readings were extremely informative and captivating 
no weaknesses
The course is strong in its content with the overall themes it provided. I wish we got more insight into the grading expectations for each assignment.
The course was highly interesting and the guest speakers amazing
A great course overall. The concentrated focus on aid in the beginning of the course was kind of dense, if it was more broken up it may have been easier to take in.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Most successful was the short lecture-lets followed by small tutorial pod discussion sections. What could be improved is the engagement to in-class speakers. There could be more room for improvement in that regard.
Recorded lectures were incredibly helpful as it gave me the flexibility to view when needed and also to rewatch prior classes. They definitely should be kept.

I really liked how lectures were pre-recorded and discussion sections were held during class time. However, I wish sections could be a bit longer. 20 minutes were sometimes not enough time to discuss the readings. Also, having shorter recorded lectures was soo helpful, especially when students are burned out from Zoom and online learning.

Mini lectures were perfect for cutting up screen time! And assignments were very considerate of students' time and capacity to do work during zoom university. Both Professor Simon and the TFs were incredibly flexible and understanding and were not stingy with accommodations or with extensions (and I still learned a TON). This class was a great example for how classes SHOULD be taught during a pandemic!

I liked the pods that were created because I got to interact with Professor Simon and my classmates on a personal basis. I wished we had more virtual double pods because it was nice to meet and talk with the other students in the class. I also really enjoyed the speakers and believe they were highlights of the course!

I think the mini-lectures were very helpful because watching hour-long lecture videos is difficult. I also enjoyed the small in person tutorials, and it was nice to have that since all my other classes were online. I generally prefer synchronous lectures, but this course's format worked well.
Pods could be structured better but at large this course and the professor made an exceptional effort to adapt to COVID and Zoom that I think was successful.
Post lectures on time--he pretended to be helping us out but made our lives so much harder by not doing so.

I think there need to be significantly less pre recorded lectures. They were overwhelming to watch at times. I think the live lectures were often a waste of time because it was difficult to pay attention with all of the zoom fatigue.
Professor and TA were very accommodating and understanding which made getting through the course virtually and at this time that much more manageable
The in person tutorial was extremely useful

I think the tutorial pods worked very well, as they made the lecture feel more seminar-like with greater opportunities for engagement and getting to talk to the professor and the TF. The pre-recorded lectures, however, could be uploaded more regularly.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. I found the material very engaging and if the student was interested in it i would likewise recommend it to them.
No, I think don't think this course is well organized, and especially for someone that does not have a background in international relations it is very easy to get lost in this course.

Of course. I think it is a phenomenal class and every Yale student would benefit from taking it. It is a section of the world that most of us do not focus on that is important to understand its political and economic history, as well as, what it could look like in the future.
not really. but if you're interested in the subject matter, go for it

Yeah, professor simon was very accomodating when he was thinking about this course. He made sure to keep recorded lectures short, assign papers and quizzes instead of a big final, and even hold a 20-minute discussion section during class. I feel like I learned so much without being overly stressed from this class, which doesn't happen often at Yale.

Absolutely! Professor Simon is a wonderful professor (and the TFs were so great as well)! The class is a great intro to understanding both International Relations as a whole, but certainly as it pertains to Africa. I was afraid the course would treat Africa as too much of a monolith, but was pleasantly surprised with the amount of specificity and nuance with which the continent was addressed with. Great class all around!

I would recommend this course to a student who is genuinely interested in learning more of Africa in international relations, and doesn't mind heavy readings and participating in class discussions. If you struggle with writing, I would suggest going to office hours to understand how to prepare for the in-class essays, and maybe look for a writing tutor to help improve your writing skills before and after writing assessments. Your experience in this class depends on how much work you put into it!
Yes. If you're interested in international politics and don't know much about Africa, you'll learn a lot from this course. Professor Simon is great.
Yes, especially a student in the AFST major - but it's very accessible for anyone outside the major as well!
I would recommend this course because it was not a hard course to take. However, it was not particularly engaging, but if you don't care about that, I would take this course.
Yes, Professor Simon has curated a holistically organized course on the varying aspects of African International Relations.
Yes! This is a great entry-level course to understand Africa in International Relations.
Yes - it is very interesting and more people should learn about this.
Yes, especially if they want to learn more about Africa and the political forces that shape the continent.

I would recommend this course to another student if they're interested in African politics within international institutions and how African countries interact with each other. Overall a great course. However be aware it is not a comparative government focus, I know some students going in who were a little confused of the difference.
